716388f.text:
Astor Place, north side, west from Lafayette Street to Broadway, showing prominently the Mercantile Library's Clinton Hall. This structure was the former Astor Place Opera House, remodelled in 1854 for the Association on their removal from Nassau and Beekman Street's. A new building will be erected here in 1891 for their purpose. The library was founded November 9, 1820, by clerks of merchants. In 1821, in one room at 49 Fulton Street, it had 150 members and 700 volumes. In 1826, in the building of Harper & Bros. in Cliff Street, it had 6000 books. In 1828 the merchants made enthusiastic by the achievements of the clerks, organized the Clinton Hall Association for the purpose of giving a building to the library. This association, in 1830, erected the first Clinton Hall on the corner of Nassau and Beekman Streets. The building herewith shown is the second Clinton Hall. On the right is East 8th Street; Broadway is at the left.

Prior to 1891

Gift of Urbrook Collection
716388f.folder: Astor Place & Lafayette Street, Manhattan, NY

720796f-a.text:
425-37 Lafayette Street, east side, south of Astor Place, showing the former Astor Library vacant and prior to the occupancy of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society (HIAS). Note the moving vans and the "For Sale" sign.
1911
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

720795f-a.text:
425-437 Lafayette Street, east side, south of Astor Place, (as viewed in a northeastward direction), showing a 3-story building formerly occupied by the Astor Library. It is now used by the Hebrew Aid Society;
better known as the H.I.A.S.
August 12, 1937.
George D. Chinn.
